title: How to Condition Your Hair With Homemade Products

methods.name: Moisturizing with a Coconut Oil Treatment

steps.headline: Select a high quality coconut oil.
steps.description: When using coconut oil on your hair, choose virgin or unrefined coconut oil. These coconut oils are less processed with no added chemicals, so they contain more nutrients that are beneficial and safer for your hair. High quality coconut oils are pure white when solid and clear when liquid. You can use either a solid or a liquid coconut oil as long as it is high quality.

steps.headline: Warm 2 to 8 tablespoons (120 mL) of coconut oil until it's melted.
steps.description: If your coconut oil is in solid form (as most products will be when you purchase them), warm 2 to 8 tablespoons (120 mL) on the stove or in the microwave until the solid has turned into a liquid. Remove the oil from the heat right when it has melted completely–you do not want the oil to get too hot, as you will be applying it to your hair. The amount you use is entirely based on how much hair you have. If you have short hair that is above your chin, for example, begin with 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of coconut oil. If you have long, thick hair, you may need up to 8 tablespoons (120 mL) to cover your whole head. Before applying the oil to your hair, gently touch the surface of the melted oil with your finger to make sure that it has not gotten too hot. If the oil is uncomfortably hot to the touch, wait a few minutes and test it again.

steps.headline: Massage the coconut oil into your hair.
steps.description: Once the coconut oil has melted, dip your fingers into the oil and gently message it into a section of your hair for about 1 minute. Repeat this until all your hair is covered in the coconut oil. It might be a good idea to wear clothes that you don’t mind staining with oil, or you can wrap a towel around your shoulders to protect your clothing. You can also apply the oil to your hair by slowly pouring it onto your head. To avoid making a mess, do this either in the shower or pour slowly while holding your head over the sink.

steps.headline: Leave the coconut oil in your hair for at least 30 minutes.
steps.description: To give the oil enough time to strengthen and add shine to your hair, leave it to rest in your hair for at least 30 minutes. You can leave your hair uncovered, or you can protect your clothes and surroundings by putting on a shower cap, or by lightly wrapping your hair in a towel. If your hair is particularly dry, you can leave the coconut oil in your hair overnight. To do this, cover your hair with a towel or shower cap. You may also want to cover your pillow with a towel so that the oil does not stain your pillowcase.

steps.headline: Rinse out the coconut oil mask.
steps.description: After leaving the coconut oil to condition your hair for at least 30 minutes, wash it out thoroughly with your regular shampoo. If your hair tends to absorb a lot of product, you may need to shampoo more than once to keep your hair from looking oily after. Coconut oil tends to weigh a bit heavily in hair, so you will likely want to skip using a bottled conditioner for at least one wash after the coconut oil wash.

steps.headline: Repeat 1 to 3 times per week.
steps.description: For best results, apply coconut oil to your hair every week. If your hair is particularly damaged or dry, you can use a coconut oil conditioning mask up to 3 times per week. If your hair is oily, however, you will likely want to stick to 1 treatment per week.

steps.headline: Mash up a ripe banana.
steps.description: Select a ripened banana and remove the peel. In a clean bowl, mash up the banana with a fork until it is as smooth as possible. You can also peel the banana and drop it into a blender or food processor. Blend for a few seconds until the banana is completely smooth.

steps.headline: Mix in honey, milk, a raw egg, and/or olive oil.
steps.description: For added nutrients, add 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of honey, 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of milk, 1 egg, and/or 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of olive oil. You can mix all of these at once, or just add one or a few of these add-ins depending on your hair type and desired effect. Use a fork to stir, or add to your blender or food processor until your add-ins are completely mixed with the mashed banana. Olive oil and honey are both highly conditioning and can help prevent breakage and promote hair growth. Milk helps strengthen your hair and can make it extra shiny. Eggs contain vitamins A and E, as well as biotin, which help promote healthy growth. Bananas are high in potassium and contain a lot of moisture all on their own, so feel free to skip add-ins. You will still end up with a great conditioner that can help prevent split ends and soften your hair.

steps.headline: Apply the banana mask to your hair.
steps.description: Scoop a bit of the banana mask mixture into your hands, about 2 to 3 tablespoons (44 mL) at a time. Rub the mask into a section of your hair. If you have split ends, spend a few seconds concentrating on rubbing the banana mask into the ends of your hair. Repeat this until all your hair is covered. Discard any leftover banana mask. If your scalp tends to be dry, rub the mask into your hair but leave about a dollop or so left. Massage this last bit of banana mask into your scalp for about 1 minute. It might be a good idea to wear clothes that you don’t mind staining, or you can wrap a towel around your shoulders to protect your clothing.

steps.headline: Let the banana mask sit on your hair for 30 minutes.
steps.description: This will give your hair ample time to absorb the nutrients. You can leave your hair uncovered, or you can protect your clothes and surroundings by putting on a shower cap, or by lightly wrapping your hair in a towel. If your hair tends to be oily and you have added olive oil into your mixture, wash the banana mask out after 15 minutes to avoid absorbing too much oil into your hair.

steps.headline: Rinse out the banana mask.
steps.description: Using your regular shampoo, wash out the banana mask thoroughly. If you used honey or olive oil in your mixture, you may need to shampoo more than once to remove all of the treatment from your hair. If you used olive oil (which is quite dense), you will likely want to skip using a bottled conditioner for at least one wash after the banana mask to avoid weighing down your hair.

steps.headline: Repeat 1 to 3 times per week.
steps.description: For best results, use your banana mask on your hair every week, up to 3 times per week depending on your hair type and add-ins. Feel free to experiment with different add-ins until you find what works best for your hair. If you plan to continuously add olive oil in and your hair is particularly damaged or dry, you can use your banana mask up to 3 times per week. If your hair is oily, however, you will likely want to stick to one treatment per week.

methods.name: Adding Nutrients with an Avocado Conditioning Paste

steps.headline: Mash 1/2 of a ripe avocado.
steps.description: Cut an avocado in half using a sharp knife and carefully remove the pit. In a clean bowl, mash 1/2 of the avocado with a fork until no chunks remain. You can also spoon the avocado into a blender or food processor and blend for a few seconds until smooth. Make sure that you use a ripe avocado so that you can easily break down any chunks and mash or blend until smooth. If your hair is very thick and/or long, you might need to use the whole avocado. If you only use half though, you can store the avocado half for future use.

steps.headline: Mix in essential oils, a raw egg, olive oil, and/or yogurt.
steps.description: For added nutrients, add 1 egg, 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of plain yogurt, 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of olive oil, or a few drops of your favorite essential oil, such as peppermint or lavender. You can mix all of these at once, or just add one or a few of these add-ins depending on your hair type and desired effect. Use a fork to stir, or add to your blender or food processor until your add-in is completely mixed with the mashed avocado. Olive oil is highly conditioning and can help prevent breakage and promote hair growth. Yogurt helps strengthen your hair and can make it extra shiny. Eggs contain vitamins A and E, as well as biotin, which help promote healthy growth. Essential oils add nutrients and can help mask any unpleasant smells. Avocado alone is rich in antioxidants, essential fatty acids, and vitamins, so feel free to skip this step if you just want to use a simple avocado conditioner. If you are using the whole avocado instead of just half, double the add-ins. For example, for a whole avocado worth of paste, you will need 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of plain yogurt.

steps.headline: Massage the avocado paste into clean, damp hair.
steps.description: Using your hands, scoop up a dollop of the avocado paste and massage it into a section of your hair for about 1 minute. Repeat this process until all of your hair is covered and you have used all of the paste. If you have really thick and/or long hair, you may need to make a bit more of the paste at this point to cover all of your hair. It might be a good idea to wear clothes that you don’t mind staining, or you can wrap a towel around your shoulders to protect your clothing.

steps.headline: Leave the avocado paste in your hair for 15 minutes.
steps.description: This will give your hair ample time to absorb the nutrients from the avocado paste. You can leave your hair uncovered, or you can protect your clothes and surroundings by putting on a shower cap, or by lightly wrapping your hair in a towel.

steps.headline: Rinse out with water.
steps.description: After you have let the avocado paste sit in your hair for 15 minutes, wash it out thoroughly with water. Once the mixture is rinsed out of your hair, dry and style your hair as usual. Your hair should feel extra soft and smooth. Avocado paste alone should not make your hair greasy or weighed down, so you shouldn’t need to use shampoo to get it all out. If you use olive oil or an egg as add-ins, however, you may need to use your regular shampoo to get all of the treatment out.

steps.headline: Repeat once every 2 weeks.
steps.description: For best results, condition your hair with an avocado paste once every 2 weeks. This will keep your hair moisturized and shiny without weighing it down. Feel free to experiment with different add-ins every 2 weeks until you find what works best for your hair.

steps.headline: Pour plain yogurt into a bowl.
steps.description: Yogurt is high in protein and lactic acid, making it a great base for a homemade hair conditioner. To begin, scoop or pour ⁄2 cup (120 mL) to 1 cup (240 mL) of plain, unflavored yogurt into a bowl, depending on how long and thick your hair is. You can use regular yogurt or Greek yogurt. Make sure that you use unflavored yogurt, as some flavored yogurts contain fruits and/or additives that may be harmful to your hair.

steps.headline: Mix in a raw egg, olive oil, essential oils, and/or honey.
steps.description: To add nutrients to your yogurt conditioner, mix in 1 egg, 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of olive oil, about 6 drops of your favorite essential oils, or about 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of honey for every ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of yogurt. You can mix all of these at once, or just add one or a few of these add-ins depending on your hair type and desired effect. Olive oil and honey can help prevent breakage and promote hair growth, while eggs may help promote healthy growth. Essential oils, such as lavender and peppermint, add nutrients and can help mask any unpleasant smells.

steps.headline: Apply the yogurt conditioner to clean, shampooed hair.
steps.description: Using your hands, apply the yogurt conditioner to your hair little by little, working through one section of hair at a time. Repeat this process until all of your hair is covered and you have used all of the yogurt conditioner. It might be a good idea to wear clothes that you don’t mind staining, or you can wrap a towel around your shoulders to protect your clothing.

steps.headline: Let the yogurt conditioner rest in your hair for 15 to 20 minutes.
steps.description: This will give your hair ample time to absorb the nutrients from the yogurt and any add-ins. You can leave your hair uncovered, or you can protect your clothes and surroundings by putting on a shower cap, or by lightly wrapping your hair in a towel.

steps.headline: Rinse out thoroughly with warm water.
steps.description: Either in the shower or carefully over the sink, wash the yogurt out of your hair completely. If you have added in olive oil, honey, or an egg, you will likely need use your regular shampoo again in order to fully remove the treatment from your hair. Shampooing may also help you get rid of any lingering dairy smell. Dry and style your hair as usual.

steps.headline: Reapply your yogurt conditioner every other week.
steps.description: For best results, condition your hair with yogurt every other week. You can try out different add-ins to find what works best for your hair.

Applying a Yogurt Conditioner Pour plain yogurt into a bowl.
Yogurt is high in protein and lactic acid, making it a great base for a homemade hair conditioner.
To begin, scoop or pour ⁄2 cup (120 mL) to 1 cup (240 mL) of plain, unflavored yogurt into a bowl, depending on how long and thick your hair is.
You can use regular yogurt or Greek yogurt.
Make sure that you use unflavored yogurt, as some flavored yogurts contain fruits and/or additives that may be harmful to your hair.
Mix in a raw egg, olive oil, essential oils, and/or honey.

To add nutrients to your yogurt conditioner, mix in 1 egg, 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of olive oil, about 6 drops of your favorite essential oils, or about 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of honey for every ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of yogurt.
You can mix all of these at once, or just add one or a few of these add-ins depending on your hair type and desired effect.
Olive oil and honey can help prevent breakage and promote hair growth, while eggs may help promote healthy growth.
Essential oils, such as lavender and peppermint, add nutrients and can help mask any unpleasant smells.
Apply the yogurt conditioner to clean, shampooed hair.
Using your hands, apply the yogurt conditioner to your hair little by little, working through one section of hair at a time.
Repeat this process until all of your hair is covered and you have used all of the yogurt conditioner.
It might be a good idea to wear clothes that you don’t mind staining, or you can wrap a towel around your shoulders to protect your clothing.
Let the yogurt conditioner rest in your hair for 15 to 20 minutes.
This will give your hair ample time to absorb the nutrients from the yogurt and any add-ins.
You can leave your hair uncovered, or you can protect your clothes and surroundings by putting on a shower cap, or by lightly wrapping your hair in a towel.
Rinse out thoroughly with warm water.
Either in the shower or carefully over the sink, wash the yogurt out of your hair completely.
If you have added in olive oil, honey, or an egg, you will likely need use your regular shampoo again in order to fully remove the treatment from your hair.
Shampooing may also help you get rid of any lingering dairy smell.
Dry and style your hair as usual.
Reapply your yogurt conditioner every other week.
For best results, condition your hair with yogurt every other week.
You can try out different add-ins to find what works best for your hair.
